div.p: What you really want, if you're government, is to make sure that you create service end
points that will allow outside developers to build applications against your data. That's
something that is in the Government Digital Strategy, it's like - we're not just going
to build websites and apps, we're going to build web services.
Because when you publish those end points then you can have a really productive hackathaon,
somebody can say 'here's this government data, I'm going to use it in a way that nobody expected',
and that's when you get that incredible revolution. On the the things that I've talked about for
the last couple of years is the notion that Government needs to start thinking of itself
as a platform. In the same way that Apple re-thought the mobile phone. In the old days
with mobile phones the vendors went in the back room with a couple of developers and
companies and came up with 30 applications 'this is the phone'. Apple turned it into
a platform and suddenly there are now 700,000 applications on the iPhone.
And to me a real mark of success will be first of all when government has figured out what
is the minimal set of things that it absolutely needs to do and then exposes a robust rich
set of service end points that will allow people out in the private sector add additional
value to that minimal must-do set of things. Then we can hit some real magic because we'll
get more and more services for citizens with more and more ingenuity without any procurement
at all because the government made it possible for people outside to build interesting things.
I'm just reminded of a wonderful passage in Ben Zander's TED talk from a few years back.
He opened with an old story of the first British shoe salesman who went to Africa.
There were two different salesmen, and one said "Uh! There's no opportunity here. Nobody
here wears shoes" and the other one said "Send more people! Nobody here wears shoes!"
